attributes.title: The Connotation of Obesity and Its Effect on Body Satisfaction
attributes.description:
This is a replication study of this paper:  Hoyt, C. L., Burnette, J. L., & Auster-Gussman, L. (2014). “Obesity is a disease”: examining the  self-regulatory impact of this public-health message. Psychological Science, 25(4), 997-1002. 
We are looking to examine the connotation on the word obesity and its effects on certain psychological processes. Specifically looking at its effects on body satisfaction and attitudes towards obese people. Participants will read one of two articles, which either present the "obesity is a disease" message or a control message and then complete an online survey to assess body satisfaction and obesity biases.

q2.value:
Does obesity as a disease message alter psychological processes including body satisfaction and concerns about weight? 
                   Our hypothesis is that the disease message will alter psychological processes, namely reducing bodily dissatisfaction in the participants. The original study found that the disease message did lower bodily dissatisfaction, especially for those participants who were obese. 

Does the obesity as a disease message alter attitudes towards obese people?
            We hypothesis that the disease message will have an effect on attitudes towards obese people. Mainly, that it will lower the  negative attitudes or biases towards obesity and obese people.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: 2 independent group design. The main IV is obesity message manipulated by the random assignment to 1 of 2 articles, which either present a disease message or a control message. Participants are randomly assigned within the online survey.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: A convenience sample of students from the host university will be collected. Participants will be recruited online, via a psychology participation pool and general online recruitment. Some participants, specifically those in the introductory psychology course will receive credit towards research participation requirements. The exclusion criteria will include not being a student at the host university, experiencing technical difficulties, and failing the attention check added into the survey.

q11.value: Sample goal is 150 participants. The original study included 360, however, a 2.5x sample is not feasible for the experimental time frame.

q12.value: The sample size is mainly based on the limitations of the study, including the time frame in which the experiment is run. This study is being done for a class so the time frame until the end of the semester is about 2-3 weeks of online recruitment. It is not possible to be able to recruit 2.5x the number of participants for the current study.

q13.value: The data collection will stop when there is no longer time in the semester to collect data. This is expected to be about 2-3 weeks of data collection.  There is no sample size target that will end data collection.

question.value: Obesity Message from articles (disease or control) as a means to manipulate connotations and beliefs or participants.

There will be 4 variables measured in this experiment. 
Body dissatisfaction measured though Contour Drawing Rating Scale where participants are asked to indicate their current body shape and their ideal body shape. 
Body Satisfaction measured on a 69 item scale that includes a 5 point likert scale. We will calculate scale average
Attitudes towards obese people measured on a 20 item likert scale ranging on a 6 point scale from strongly disagree to strongly agree. 
Demographics variables will also be collected which include age, gender, education level, and race

Does obesity as a disease message alter psychological processes including body satisfaction and concerns about weight? 
             We will compare body satisfaction scores for the disease and control conditions, from both body satisfaction scales  We will calculate the mean difference and its CI as well as Cohen’s d and its CI. We expect the effect to be positive (increased body satisfaction for disease condition). 

Does the obesity as a disease message alter attitudes towards obese people? 
               We will compare attituded towards obese people scores for the disease and control conditions.  We will calculate the mean difference and its CI as well as Cohen’s d and its CI. We expect the effect to be negative (decreased biases for disease condition).

q20.value: The exclusion criteria will include not being a student at the host university, experiencing technical difficulties, and failing the attention check

q21.value: As in original study, no imputation or other strategy, just omission of missing responses analysis-by-analysis

q22.value: Exploratory data will include a correlation coefficient and CI analysis between the two body satisfacton scales used to asses the convergent validity.

                   Our hypothesis is that the disease message will alter psychological processes, namely reducing bodily dissatisfaction in the participants. The original study found that the disease message did lower bodily dissatisfaction, especially for those participants who were obese. 

Does the obesity as a disease message alter attitudes towards obese people?
            We hypothesis that the disease message will have an effect on attitudes towards obese people. Mainly, that it will lower the  negative attitudes or biases towards obesity and obese people.

q2.value: Lanier Frush Holt, Sophie Kjaervik , Brad J. Bushman

q3.value:
Previous research shows that playing a violent video game as a black avatar elicits more aggression than playing the same game as a white avatar (Yang et al., 2014), perhaps because black people are stereotypically more aggressive than white people. We want to extend that research by examining Arab / Muslim avatars, which are stereotypically viewed as terrorists that target innocent bystanders (especially in video games). 

Before gameplay, participants will be angered by a fictitious partner. After gameplay, participants will be given the chance to aggress against that person or against an innocent bystander.

This experiment follows directly from social learning theory and social cognitive theory, so it has a firm theoretical foundation. It also has applied significance if we show that playing violent games reinforces stereotypes about Muslims / Arab people and about black people.

q4.value: We predict the highest levels of displaced aggression from participants who play as an Arab / Muslim avatar, and the highest levels of direct aggression from participants who play as a black avatar.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Our experiment would be a 3 (black vs. Arab vs. white avatar) X 2 (direct vs. displaced aggression).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Researchers are in the process of data collection, but have not downloaded or analyzed the data. Furthermore, the sample size currently collected is far from the number deemed necessary by the power analysis.

question.value:
Potential participants for the full study will be recruited from the School of Communication Research Experience Program (C-REP). On the C-REP website, potential participants will read a recruitment statement and choose whether to sign up. Participants will be awarded class credit for their participation.

All non-white and Muslim participants will be excluded from the study. In order to properly assess the aggressive behavior of those who play as Black and Arab/Muslim avatars, it is necessary to maintain the most consistent and homogenous sample in terms of racial background. This allows for a stronger causal claim with respect to the impact of video games and aggressive behavior. There are ample study opportunities and alternative assignments that can be completed for class credit, and therefore no adverse effects due to the exclusion of non-white individuals are anticipated. Students under 18 years old are excluded so they can provide consent to participate.

q13.value: 384 participants who are white and 18 years of age or older.

q14.value: A power analysis reveals that 64 participants are needed per group to detect a medium-sized effect (d = 0.50) with power = .80 (the recommended power level) at the .05 (two-sided) significance level. Thus, we will need to test 384 participants (64 per group X 6 groups).

question.value:
Avatar race / ethnicity:
(1) Arab / Muslim character named Mohammed
(2) Black character named DeShawn
(3) White character named Jake

Aggression target:
Participants will give hot sauce to a partner who hates spicy food 
(1) Direct aggression (i.e., the partner criticized their essay)
(2) Displaced aggression (i.e., the partner did not read their essay)

The main outcome variable is aggression, defined as the weight (in grams) of hot sauce the participant gives their partner (who dislikes spicy food).

We also measure attitudes toward different racial groups after we measure aggression using feeling thermometers (see attached).
Data will be analyzed using a 3 X 2 ANOVA

attributes.title: Assessing data sharing practices and computational reproducibility of articles awarded Open Data badges
attributes.description: This study is an assessment of articles that have been awarded an Open Data badge, one of the badges offered as part of the Open Science Badges initiative developed and overseen by the Center for Open Science (https://cos.io/badges). The study will assess the data availability for all articles awarded an Open Data badge published between 2014 and 2019 inclusive. For a subsample of articles published in the journals Psychological Science and American Journal of Political Science, the study will assess the presence of metadata and licencing information for shared data, perform minimal computational reproducibility checks of simple summary statistics reported in articles, and perform checks of the computational reproducibility of some statistical results reported in articles.

summary.value: All preregistration details are in the document preregistration_assessing_open_data_badges.pdf.

registration_responses.summary: All preregistration details are in the document preregistration_assessing_open_data_badges.pdf.

attributes.title: Zika Startup Evaluation Manuscript Extended Data
attributes.description: In 2018, the USAID Applying Science to Strengthen and Improve Systems (ASSIST) Project started a new partnership with four Eastern and Southern Caribbean countries impacted by the Zika virus: Antigua and Barbuda, Dominica, St. Kitts and Nevis, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines.  The goal of the project was to provide short-term technical assistance (STTA) to strengthen the health systems’ capacity to detect newborns and young children potentially affected by Zika and to address their health needs.  To meet these objectives, ASSIST developed an innovative approach based on its existing model for service delivery improvement. An evaluation was conducted to document the STTA startup activities, to identify enabling and constraining factors, and to capture lessons learned.

summary.value: Project name: Evaluation of the rapid, multi-country, parallel process, multi-tasking approach to startup of short-term technical assistance to improve service delivery in newborn and child health in the context of USAID’s Zika response in four Eastern and Southern Caribbean countries. Related files: 1) STTA evaluation reviewed documents: (meeting records, activity plans, timelines, presentations, trip reports); 2) interview guides; 3) consent form

data.name: ASSIST Zika Evaluation Study Consent Form.docx

extra.selectedFileName: ASSIST Zika Evaluation Study Consent Form.docx

registration_responses.summary: Project name: Evaluation of the rapid, multi-country, parallel process, multi-tasking approach to startup of short-term technical assistance to improve service delivery in newborn and child health in the context of USAID’s Zika response in four Eastern and Southern Caribbean countries. Related files: 1) STTA evaluation reviewed documents: (meeting records, activity plans, timelines, presentations, trip reports); 2) interview guides; 3) consent form

uploader.file_name: ASSIST Zika Evaluation Study Consent Form.docx

attributes.title: Support for Executive Decree Authority in Crisis
attributes.description: It is commonly thought that the public is more tolerant of the exercise of executive power in crisis situations like wars. We investigate this with a nationally representative, online survey gauging support for a set of unilateral policy changes in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

q2.value:
(H1) Respondents will be less supportive of policy responses to COVID-19 if they are described as being implemented by executive order, relative through congressional legislation.

(H2) Respondents in areas with more confirmed cases of COVID-19 will be more supportive of policy responses, generally.

(H3) The executive order penalty described in H1 will be lower for respondents in areas with more confirmed cases of COVID-19.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q5.value: Data collection began with a "soft" launch on March 29 (N~100), with the subsequent responses collected on March 30. This pre-registration was completed March 31. The coauthor completing the pre-registration was not directly involved in obtaining subject respondents and was blinded to the data as it was collected.

question.value: Between subjects design with 2 factors (policy enacted by executive order, policy enacted by legislation).

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Participants were recruited through the Lucid Theorem portal at a cost of $1 per complete, with subjects paid on terms set by Lucid.

q12.value: Our sample size was chosen based on cost, timing, and our hypotheses. Confirmed cases of COVID-19 were changing rapidly at the time of fielding, which is the moderating variable for our third hypothesis. Data on confirmed COVID-19 cases exist at the county-level. We wanted to ensure, at minimum, adequate respondent coverage by state.

question.value: We manipulated the way in which COVID-19 policy responses are described. The two levels are "enacted by executive order" and "enacted via legislation."

We will measure the following contextual variables, in addition to demographic characteristics provided by Lucid: knowledge of the number of local covid-19 cases, degree of concern over personal health, presidential approval, approval of Trump's handling of covid-19, approval of Congress' handling of covid-19, approval of state/local government handling of covid-19. Our outcome measures are support for each of the following policies: detaining infected persons unwilling to quarantine, interest-free loans to businesses, delaying the November 2020 elections, dissolving Congress, lifting all stay-at-home orders, restricted what news media could publish, speeding vaccine development, prohibiting travel between states, nationalizing production of medical supplies, and releasing federal prisoners from detention. See attached file for details. (Note, the federal prison question is not included in this draft because at the time of pre-registration, the coauthor responsible was blinded from access the survey.)
No indices will be used.

H1-H3 will be tested with ordered logistic regressions that include the support questions as an outcome, with the treatment variable and vector of demographic covariates as regressors. The key moderating variable for H3 will be the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases in the nearest county the respondent is located. This data was not collected at the time of registration, but we anticipate it will require log-transformation. 

We intend to use a simple manipulation check that determines whether the respondent could recall the treatment.

registration_responses.q2:
(H1) Respondents will be less supportive of policy responses to COVID-19 if they are described as being implemented by executive order, relative through congressional legislation.

(H2) Respondents in areas with more confirmed cases of COVID-19 will be more supportive of policy responses, generally.

(H3) The executive order penalty described in H1 will be lower for respondents in areas with more confirmed cases of COVID-19.

attributes.title: Motivations for Instructor Selection
attributes.description: This study examines how Columbia undergraduates select their instructors each semester. Participants choose between two hypothetical instructors based on a variety of factors including gender and ethnicity (both signaled by name), class time, class location, grading reputation, whether the instructor is a graduate student or a professor, and whether they have a teaching award. The researcher is particularly interested in whether the gender or ethnicity of an instructor impacts their rate of selection.

q1.value: Motivations of instructor selection: examining how students choose their professors

q3.value: The initial study was performed in the fall of 2019 as part of an undergraduate Experimental Methods course. The sample was small and recruited in-person. This iteration of the study uses e-mail recruitment and a larger sample (N=236). Specific differences between each study can be found in the Updated Pre-Analysis Plan posted to OSF.

q4.value: The researcher believes that participants will favor instructors that are their own gender and ethnicity. These effects will be larger in situations where each hypothetical instructor has a Gold Nugget on CULPA

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: The study is designed as a conjoint experiment where each subject is presented with two potential profiles of instructors they can take a certain class with. Participants are asked to choose between these two profiles depending on the factors ascribed to each hypothetical instructor. All factors are randomized but they appear in the same order in each profile (for easy comparison for the participant and to avoid issues of comprehension). All participants were sampled randomly from the Columbia Student Directory.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Data has been collected via Qualtrics and has not been examined by the researcher in any capacity (the data has not been downloaded off the survey site).

question.value: I will sample participants from the Columbia Student Directory, selecting undergraduates in the school of Engineering, the College, and the school of General Studies. Participants will be recruited via email (three total emails over the course of a week) and invited to take the survey.

q13.value: The minimum sample for this study will be 200 Columbia undergraduates.

question.value: All factors (Name, Professor/Graduate Student, Grading Reputation, Class Time, Class Location, and Teaching Accolade/No Teaching Accolade) present in instructor profiles will be randomly selected as is customary in conjoint experiments.

The outcome variables of interest are the effect of gender and ethnicity (signaled by name) of the hypothetical professor on participants choosing to take a course with them.

Covariates of interest include the subject's gender and ethnicity and potential interaction effects between gender and ethnicity, class and ethnicity, and class and gender of the hypothetical professors.

Data will be analyzed both with the cjoint R package and a simple regression analysis. Interaction effects will also be analyzed for gender and ethnicity, class and ethnicity, and gender and class of the hypothetical instructors. Data will be subset into gender and ethnic groups, with the size of each group reported. If a group is deemed to have too few observations to yield reliable results, it will be stated in the paper.

attributes.title: Esophageal defect repair by tissue engineered scaffolds: A systematic review of experimental studies and proportional meta-analysis.
attributes.description: The traditional technique of gastrointestinal reconstruction of the esophagus after esophagectomy presents plenty of complications. Hence, tissue engineering has been introduced as an effective artificial alternative with potentially fewer complications. Three types of esophageal scaffolds have been used in experimental studies so far. therefore, we performed a meta-analysis in order to present the postoperative outcomes after esophageal replacement with artificial scaffolds and the investigation of possible factors that affect these outcomes.

summary.value:
Background: The traditional technique of gastrointestinal reconstruction of the esophagus after esophagectomy presents plenty of complications. Hence, tissue engineering has been introduced as an effective artificial alternative with potentially fewer complications. Three types of esophageal scaffolds have been used in experimental studies so far. The aim of our meta-analysis is to present the postoperative outcomes after esophageal replacement with artificial scaffolds and the investigation of possible factors that affect these outcomes. 
Methods: The present proportional meta-analysis was designed using the PRISMA and AMSTAR guidelines. We searched Medline, Scopus, Clinicaltrials.gov, EMBASE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials CENTRAL and Google Scholar databases from inception until February 2020.
Results: Overall, thirty-two studies were included that recruited 587 animals. The pooled morbidity after esophageal scaffold implantation was 53.4% (95% CI = 36.6 to 70.0%). The pooled survival interval was 111.1 days (95% CI = 65.5 to 156.8 days). Graft stenosis (46%), post-operative dysphagia (15%) and anastomotic leak (12%) were the most common complications after esophageal scaffold implantation. Animals that underwent an implantation of an artificial scaffold in the thoracic part of their esophagus presented higher survival rates than animals that underwent scaffold implantation in the cervical or abdominal part of their esophagus (p<0.001 and p=0.011, respectively). 
Conclusion: Tissue engineering seems to offer an effective alternative for the repair of esophageal defects in animal models. Nevertheless, issues like graft stenosis and lack of motility of the esophageal scaffolds need to be addressed in future experimental studies before scaffolds can be tested in human trials.

registration_responses.summary:
Background: The traditional technique of gastrointestinal reconstruction of the esophagus after esophagectomy presents plenty of complications. Hence, tissue engineering has been introduced as an effective artificial alternative with potentially fewer complications. Three types of esophageal scaffolds have been used in experimental studies so far. The aim of our meta-analysis is to present the postoperative outcomes after esophageal replacement with artificial scaffolds and the investigation of possible factors that affect these outcomes. 
Methods: The present proportional meta-analysis was designed using the PRISMA and AMSTAR guidelines. We searched Medline, Scopus, Clinicaltrials.gov, EMBASE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials CENTRAL and Google Scholar databases from inception until February 2020.
Results: Overall, thirty-two studies were included that recruited 587 animals. The pooled morbidity after esophageal scaffold implantation was 53.4% (95% CI = 36.6 to 70.0%). The pooled survival interval was 111.1 days (95% CI = 65.5 to 156.8 days). Graft stenosis (46%), post-operative dysphagia (15%) and anastomotic leak (12%) were the most common complications after esophageal scaffold implantation. Animals that underwent an implantation of an artificial scaffold in the thoracic part of their esophagus presented higher survival rates than animals that underwent scaffold implantation in the cervical or abdominal part of their esophagus (p<0.001 and p=0.011, respectively). 
Conclusion: Tissue engineering seems to offer an effective alternative for the repair of esophageal defects in animal models. Nevertheless, issues like graft stenosis and lack of motility of the esophageal scaffolds need to be addressed in future experimental studies before scaffolds can be tested in human trials.

attributes.title: Reducing Prejudice through Self-Affirmation
attributes.description: Research suggests that self-affirmation can reduce threat in a multitude of domains (e.g., stereotype threat). Given the capacity for self-affirmation to reduce threats to the self of various types, the current work examines the capacity for self-affirmation to reduce outgroup prejudice, and the mechanisms which explain this effect.

q3.value: Research suggests that self-affirmation can reduce threat in a multitude of domains (e.g., stereotype threat). Given the capacity for self-affirmation to reduce threats to the self of various types, the current work examines the capacity for self-affirmation to reduce outgroup prejudice, and the mechanisms which explain this effect. This study will examine whether two variables (self-compassion and intergroup anxiety) mediate the relationship between self-affirmation and outgroup prejudice. It will also examine whether group identification moderates the association between two paths: the path between self-affirmation and intergroup anxiety, and the path between self-affirmation and outgroup prejudice.

q4.value:
There will be a significant interaction between self-affirmation condition and job candidate condition in predicting outgroup prejudice. Specifically, those engaged in self-affirmation will report lower levels of outgroup attitudes as compared to a control condition  (Hypothesis Ia). In addition, regarding the job candidate evaluation, those in the self-affirmation will show more favorable evaluations of the African American job candidate as compared to the control condition. Furthermore, evaluations of White American job candidate will be similar regardless of the presence or absence of self-affirmation, and similar in ratings to the African American candidate-control condition.

Intergroup anxiety will mediate the relationship between self-affirmation and prejudice: those in the self-affirmation condition will show lower levels of intergroup anxiety as compared to those in the control condition, and higher levels of intergroup anxiety will be associated with higher levels of outgroup prejudice (Hypothesis II).

Self-compassion will mediate the effect of self-affirmation on prejudice. Specifically, those in the self-affirmation condition will show higher levels of self-compassion as compared to those in the control condition; in addition, higher levels of self-compassion will be associated with lower levels of outgroup prejudice (Hypothesis III).

Group identification will moderate the association between self-affirmation and intergroup anxiety, and will moderate the association between self-affirmation and outgroup prejudice (Hypothesis IV).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study will use a 2 (self-affirmation vs. control) × 2 (African American job candidate vs. White American job candidate) between-subjects design. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a self-affirmation or control condition. Participants will also be randomly assigned to complete an evaluation for an outgroup job candidate (African American) or an ingroup job candidate (White American). Participants will also be asked to answer questions measuring the mediating variables (intergroup anxiety and self-compassion) and the moderating variable (group identification). In addition, participants will be assessed for attitudes toward African Americans. Upon completion of the study, participants will be debriefed, thanked, and compensated online.

q9.value: Block randomization will be used, set up using the Randomizer in Qualtrics survey flow. An embedded data item (condition) will be entered to assign participants to the self-affirmation or control condition, and also to the AA job candidate or WEA candidate. The presentation of the mediators and measures of outgroup prejudice will be counterbalanced. Specifically, half of the participants will be measured on the mediators (intergroup anxiety, self compassion) before the outgroup prejudice outcome variables (job candidate evaluation, outgroup attitudes); the other half of participants will be measured on the outgroup prejudice variables (job candidate evaluation, outgroup attitudes) before the mediators (intergroup anxiety, self compassion). The job candidate evaluation will always precede the outgroup attitudes measure; the intergroup anxiety measure will always precede the self-compassion scale.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via a study posting on Amazon Mechanical Turk. The study posting will include a link to a Qualtrics study. White American adults (18 years or older) will be eligible for participation. Participants will be compensated with $1.00 for their participation.

q13.value: 700 participants will be collected in the study.

q14.value: A power analysis determined that a sample size of N = 501 participants would be needed to obtain power of .95 in order to detect a small effect of .20, to examine main effects and interactions with four groups and one moderator.

question.value:
The study will use a 2 (self-affirmation vs. control) × 2 (African American job candidate vs. White American job candidate) between-subjects design. 

Self-affirmation. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a self-affirmation or control condition. Following the same procedure adopted in other studies (e.g., Badea, Bender, & Korda, 2020), all participants will be given a list of values (listed below) and will rank-order the values from most to least importance to them. Those in the self-affirmation condition will write about the value they identified as most important; those in the control condition will write about the value least important to them. 

The self-affirmation values and domains include: artistic skill, athletics, business/money, creativity, independence, music, relationships, religious values, sense of humor, politics, and spontaneity

Job candidate manipulation. The candidate manipulation will be adapted from previous self-affirmation and prejudice research (Fein & Spencer, 1997). All participants will read about the qualifications of a male job candidate (Mark Williams) and asked to make an evaluative decision about whether they would hire that candidate for an entry-level job position.  Participants will be provided with a purported LinkedIn online profile of the candidate, which lists their qualifications for the position in question. Half of the participants will be randomly assigned to evaluate an outgroup job candidate (African American); the other half of participants will evaluate an ingroup job candidate (White American). The candidates will have the same qualifications (e.g., education, work history) and their LinkedIn profiles will present the same information; the only differences between the candidates will be their ethnicity, as manipulated by a purported picture on the LinkedIn profile. As a cover story, participants will be told they will rank one candidate chosen randomly from a sample of 10 possible candidates. In actuality, all participants will evaluate one of two candidates: an ingroup or an outgroup candidate, with the exact same name and qualifications.

Following prior literature (Fein & Spencer, 1997), job candidates will be represented as “fairly well qualified for the position, but not necessarily a stellar candidate” (pp. 33). LinkedIn profile information will be adapted from previous materials posted by other researchers on OSF (https://osf.io/bcf2e/) and also taken from reviewing real LinkedIn profiles. In addition, a person with similar educational experience will provide feedback on candidate qualifications. Candidate qualifications will furthermore be pretested with a different sample to determine how well qualified the candidate qualifications are for the job position.  Photos for the purported job candidates are chosen from the Chicago Face Database (Photos BM-232 & WM-254; Ma, Correll, & Wittenbrink, 2015). The job position will be adapted from a real job ad posted online.

Intergroup anxiety. The Intergroup Anxiety scale (Stephan & Stephan, 1985) will measure negative emotions toward interacting with a group of African Americans (i.e., 0 = not at all, 9 = extremely). Participants will be asked to indicate the extent to which they feel each of six negative items (e.g., uncertain, worried, awkward, anxious, threatened, and nervous) and six positive items (e.g., comfortable, trusting, friendly, confident, safe, and at ease). Positive items will be reverse-coded, and items will be combined to form a measure of intergroup anxiety. 

Self-compassion. Self-compassion will be measured using the 12-item Self-Compassion Scale-Short Form (Raes, Pommier, Neff, & Van Gucht, 2011). An example item includes: “I try to see my failings as part of the human condition” and the scale is measured using a 5-point Likert scale (1 = Almost never, 5 = Almost always).

Group identification. Study 2 will include a measure of group identification. The 4-item importance to identity subscale of the Collective Self-Esteem scale will be used (Luhtanen & Crocker, 1992). The race-specific version of the scale will be used to examine importance of one’s identity as a White American. An example item includes “The racial/ethnic group I belong to is an important reflection of who I am” (1 = strongly disagree; 7 = strongly agree). Participants will also be asked to answer the following question: "How strongly identified do you feel toward your ethnic/racial group?" (1 = not at all strongly; 4 = very strongly). 

Outgroup attitudes. Participants will be asked to provide their attitudes toward African Americans. Following Amiot and Hornsey (2010), participants will first be given feeling thermometers (e.g., 0 to 100, cold/warm, unfriendly/friendly, distant/close, different/similar) and asked to indicate the amount of warmth they feel toward African Americans. Then, participants will be provided with a series of adjectives (i.e., intelligent, friendly, likeable, immature, cultivated, boring, talented, sympathetic, stubborn, trustworthy, bad, dishonest, truthful) and asked to indicate how they believe African Americans rank on each adjective (i.e., 1 = not at all; 9 = extremely). Negative adjectives will be reverse-coded, meaning that higher scores will indicate more positive ratings for African Americans. The feeling thermometers and adjectives will be standardized and combined to form a single index of attitudes toward African Americans. To mask the interest in collecting responses toward African Americans, participants will make feeling thermometer ratings toward 4 other racial categories (White, Hispanic, Asian, and other ethnic Americans). Participants will also rate White and other ethnic Americans on the adjectives ratings. 

Job candidate evaluation. Study 2 measures will also include a measure of outgroup prejudice as operationalized by evaluation of an outgroup job candidate (vs. an ingroup candidate). Participants’ ratings of the job candidate’s qualifications will be measured using four items used in Fein & Spencer (1997): “I feel this person would make an excellent candidate for the position in question,” “I would likely give this person serious consideration for the position in question,” “I would guess that this person is in the top 20% of people interviewed,” and “I felt favorably toward this person” (1= strongly disagree; 7= strongly agree).

First, in a regression analysis, condition (1 = self-affirmation; 0 = control), job candidate (1 = outgroup; 0 = ingroup), and their interaction will be examined as a predictor of the two prejudice outcomes: outgroup attitudes and job candidate ratings. It will be examined using contrast analyses whether the self-affirmation/outgroup conditions (3) are significantly different from the self-affirmation/ingroup (-1), control/outgroup (-1), and control/ingroup (-1) conditions. Then, to test the theoretical model depicted in Figure 2, the PROCESS macro (Version 3; Hayes, 2013) will be used to determine the parallel mediational influences of intergroup anxiety and self-compassion, and the moderating influences of group identification, on both prejudice outcomes. Group identification will be examined as a moderator of two pathways: the path between self-affirmation and intergroup anxiety, and the path between self-affirmation and outgroup attitudes. Figure 3 provides a predicted pattern of results for the self-affirmation/control and outgroup/ingroup analyses predicting outgroup prejudice.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they 1) answer zero of four attention checks correctly, 2) fail to answer one of the three manipulation checks correctly, 3) are identified as an outliers (defined as ±2.5 standard deviations above or below the mean of the outcome variable in a given analysis), 4) if they are not White American, or 5) if the IP address or MTurk ID number repeats with an additional participant in the dataset.

q23.value: Participants that fail to provide data on the self-affirmation manipulation, job evaluation manipulation, measures of prejudice, or measures of group identification, self-compassion, or intergroup anxiety, will not be analyzed.

q24.value: Potential covariates (e.g., religious affiliation, gender, political orientation) may be explored for their influences on these relationships. For example, it could be speculated that gender may influence prejudice ratings toward African Americans, given that women tend to report higher ratings toward racial outgroup members as compared to men, in prior research.

This study will examine whether two variables (self-compassion and intergroup anxiety) mediate the relationship between self-affirmation and outgroup prejudice. It will also examine whether group identification moderates the association between two paths: the path between self-affirmation and intergroup anxiety, and the path between self-affirmation and outgroup prejudice.

summary.value: This registration creates a permanent URL that will preserve data collected in association with this project (this data has also been uploaded to my GitHub account).

comments.value:
Pre-registration Amendment

This document serves as an addendum to the pre-registration previously filed for the project “Video Games and Stereotypes”. Due to the unforeseen circumstances created by the COVID-19 pandemic, the authors of this study suspended data collection prior to collecting the necessary sample size stipulated in the original pre-registration. Since it is unclear when or if data collection will resume in the near future, the authors have elected to preview the data to determine the prospects of the study. 

The onset of the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in the suspension of many face-to-face activities across university campuses. The nature of the experiment conducted in this study was particularly risky, as it involved close contact between participants and researchers, as well as opportunities to taste food items. As of the date of suspension, researchers have collected 174 of the 384 participants, which was the sample size determined necessary by power analysis. 

At this time, there is no clear indication for when face-to-face contact will resume on University campuses, which is why the authors decided to preview the collected data to determine the viability of continuing the study in the future, given the time and resources required to pursue this path. Should the current results indicate that the projected hypotheses are reasonably supported (i.e., not necessarily significant, but statistical directionality is aligned with predictions), then continuing the project is a realistic possibility. However, if hypotheses are not supported, then it is more prudent to terminate the project. 

Provided the currently sample size and the original power analysis, the criterion for the preview would be that the effects are in the predicted direction and Cohen’s d > 0.20. In particular, the central hypothesis is that displaced aggression will be highest for participants who play the violent game as an Arab/Muslim character compared to participants who played either as a Black character or a White character. The level of displaced aggression was not expected to differ for the latter two conditions. According to Cohen (1977), a “small” d = 0.20. We used d = 0.50 for our power analyses.

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

Due to the unforeseen circumstances created by the COVID-19 pandemic, the authors of this study suspended data collection prior to collecting the necessary sample size stipulated in the original pre-registration. Since it is unclear when or if data collection will resume in the near future, the authors have elected to preview the data to determine the prospects of the study. 

The onset of the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in the suspension of many face-to-face activities across university campuses. The nature of the experiment conducted in this study was particularly risky, as it involved close contact between participants and researchers, as well as opportunities to taste food items. As of the date of suspension, researchers have collected 174 of the 384 participants, which was the sample size determined necessary by power analysis. 

At this time, there is no clear indication for when face-to-face contact will resume on University campuses, which is why the authors decided to preview the collected data to determine the viability of continuing the study in the future, given the time and resources required to pursue this path. Should the current results indicate that the projected hypotheses are reasonably supported (i.e., not necessarily significant, but statistical directionality is aligned with predictions), then continuing the project is a realistic possibility. However, if hypotheses are not supported, then it is more prudent to terminate the project. 

Provided the currently sample size and the original power analysis, the criterion for the preview would be that the effects are in the predicted direction and Cohen’s d > 0.20. In particular, the central hypothesis is that displaced aggression will be highest for participants who play the violent game as an Arab/Muslim character compared to participants who played either as a Black character or a White character. The level of displaced aggression was not expected to differ for the latter two conditions. According to Cohen (1977), a “small” d = 0.20. We used d = 0.50 for our power analyses.
registration_responses.datacompletion: Yes, data collection is underway or complete
